name: Couples Therapy
summary: A form of psychotherapy designed to help intimate partners improve communication, resolve conflicts, and strengthen their relationship.
description: Couples therapy, also known as marriage counseling or relationship therapy, is a structured intervention that supports partners in navigating challenges, improving communication, fostering intimacy, and resolving conflicts. It integrates multiple therapeutic approaches, including cognitive-behavioral, emotionally focused, psychodynamic, and systemic models, depending on the therapist's training and the couple's needs. The goal is to improve relationship satisfaction and individual well-being.

contraindications: Active domestic violence without safety measures
Unwillingness of one or both partners to engage
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Safe and non-invasive, but may bring up intense emotions.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Strong—supported by multiple RCTs, particularly for Emotionally Focused Therapy and Behavioral Couples Therapy.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Demonstrated efficacy for improving relationship satisfaction, reducing conflict, and supporting recovery from infidelity or trauma.

sections.text: Couples therapy enhances relational functioning through improved communication, emotional attunement, problem-solving skills, and rebuilding trust. Different models emphasize different mechanisms, such as restructuring negative interaction cycles (EFT), increasing positive behavioral exchanges (CBT/behavioral), or uncovering unconscious dynamics (psychodynamic/systemic).

sections.preparation: Initial intake session(s) to assess relationship history, presenting concerns, and individual goals.
procedure: Assessment of relationship strengths, challenges, and attachment patterns.
Skill-building in communication, empathy, and conflict resolution.
Exploring underlying relational patterns and emotions.
Homework assignments to practice skills outside of sessions.
sections.duration: 8–20 sessions for structured therapy, longer-term for complex issues.
sections.total_treatment_time: 3–6 months for most couples; ongoing as needed.

sections.treatment_phase: Therapist-facilitated dialogue, skill practice, and exploration of emotions.

common: Temporary increase in conflict as issues surface
uncommon: Increased anxiety or sadness during exploration of deep issues
rare: Relationship dissolution if therapy reveals irreconcilable differences

absolute: Lack of partner consent to participate
relative: Severe psychiatric instability in one partner

ideal_candidates: Couples experiencing frequent conflict or emotional disconnection
Couples seeking premarital counseling or preventative support

practitioner: Licensed therapists trained in couples/relationship therapy models
facility: Private practice, counseling centers, online therapy platforms

studies: Johnson SM, Greenman PS. (2013). Emotionally focused therapy: Empirical status and future directions. Journal of Family Therapy.
Shadish WR, Baldwin SA. (2003). Meta-analysis of marriage and family therapy. Journal of Marriage and Family Therapy.
sections.limitations: Effectiveness may depend on model fit and motivation of both partners.

sections.total_treatment_cost: Varies by duration (commonly $1,200–$4,000 for a standard course)
sections.insurance_coverage: Sometimes covered under family therapy benefits, but not always
sections.cost_effectiveness: Can reduce long-term costs associated with divorce, separation, and family stress

sections.lgbtq: Affirmative couples therapy models available; attention to minority stress.
sections.premarital: Often used proactively to strengthen relationship foundations.
sections.chronic_illness: Can support couples facing medical challenges together.

items: Choice of therapeutic model (EFT, CBT, psychodynamic, systemic) should be tailored to the couple’s needs.
Therapy may clarify incompatibilities, which can lead to separation as an appropriate outcome.
Strong therapeutic alliance with both partners is essential.

items.label: Johnson SM, Greenman PS. Emotionally focused therapy: Empirical status and future directions. J Fam Ther. 2013.
Shadish WR, Baldwin SA. Meta-analysis of marriage and family therapy. J Marital Fam Ther. 2003.

seo.title: Couples Therapy
seo.description: Couples therapy, also called marriage counseling, helps partners improve communication, resolve conflict, and strengthen intimacy through evidence-based relationship interventions.
